Defective dual varieties for real spectra

Jens ForsgÃ¥rd UniversitÃ© de GenÃ¨ve, MathÃ©matiques, Villa Battelle, 1227 Carouge, Suisse. Jens.Forsgaard@unige.ch
Abstract.

We introduce an invariant of a finite point configuration AâŠ‚â„1+nğ´superscriptâ„1ğ‘›A\subset\mathbb{R}^{1+n} which we denote the cuspidal form of Ağ´A. We use this invariant to extend Esterovâ€™s characterization of dual defective point configurations to exponential sums; the dual variety associated to Ağ´A has codimension at least 222 if and only if Ağ´A does not contain any iterated circuit.

1. Introduction

The main undertaking of fewnomial theory is to bound the number of connected components of the positive part of a variety defined by a system of equations solely in terms of the number of variables nğ‘›n and the total number of monomials Nğ‘N appearing in the system. Since the constitutive monograph [10] of KhovanskiÄ­, fewnomial theory has often been studied alongside the theory of exponential sums. After all, the coordinatewise exponential map exp:â„nâ†’â„+n:â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘›\exp\colon\mathbb{R}^{n}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}_{+}^{n} is a diffeomorpism and replacing monomials zÎ±superscriptğ‘§ğ›¼z^{\alpha} by exponentials eâŸ¨w,Î±âŸ©superscriptğ‘’ğ‘¤ğ›¼e^{\langle w,\alpha\rangle} the fundamental examples (read: Descartesâ€™ rule of signs) remain valid.

Lately, fewnomial theory has also been studied from the viewpoint of Gelâ€™fand, Kapranov, and Zelevinskyâ€™s â€œAğ´A-philosophy.â€ In this approach, one considers the family of all polynomials which can be expressed using a fixed set (the support set) Ağ´A of exponent vectors Î±ğ›¼\alpha. For example, in [1] the bound on the number of positive solutions of a system of equations supported on a circuit was sharpened by considering in addition the combinatorics of Ağ´A.

Seldom has the two approaches been combined. We are aware only of [12], where the Ağ´A-discriminant and its Hornâ€“Kapranov uniformization was generalized to the case of exponential sums. We put ourself in this setting, and consider the family

(â„‚Ã—)A={fâ€‹(w)=âˆ‘Î±âˆˆAcÎ±â€‹eâŸ¨w,Î±âŸ©|cÎ±âˆˆâ„‚Ã—},superscriptsuperscriptâ„‚ğ´conditional-setğ‘“ğ‘¤subscriptğ›¼ğ´subscriptğ‘ğ›¼superscriptğ‘’ğ‘¤ğ›¼subscriptğ‘ğ›¼superscriptâ„‚(\mathbb{C}^{\times})^{A}=\bigg{\{}\,f(w)=\sum_{\alpha\in A}c_{\alpha}\,e^{\langle w,\alpha\rangle}\,\bigg{|}\,c_{\alpha}\in\mathbb{C}^{\times}\,\bigg{\}},

where AâŠ‚â„1+nğ´superscriptâ„1ğ‘›A\subset\mathbb{R}^{1+n} is a finite set, and N=#â€‹Ağ‘#ğ´N=\#A. We have many names for those we love; the support set Ağ´A is also known as the Bohr spectrum (or, simply, spectrum) of an exponential sum fâˆˆ(â„‚Ã—)Ağ‘“superscriptsuperscriptâ„‚ğ´f\in(\mathbb{C}^{\times})^{A}.

The work presented in this article emerged from an innocent question of whether a theorem of Katz [9] holds also in the framework of exponential sums. The answer is affirmative, as we show in TheoremÂ 3.5. This theorem has already seen an application in [6] to reduce a fewnomial hypersurface bound from exponential to subexponential in the dimension. Our main line of thought goes, however, in a slightly different direction.

We associate to the spectrum AâŠ‚â„1+nğ´superscriptâ„1ğ‘›A\subset\mathbb{R}^{1+n} a combinatorial invariant in the form of a homogeneous polynomial PAâ€‹(t)subscriptğ‘ƒğ´ğ‘¡P_{A}(t) of degree nğ‘›n, which we call the cuspidal form of Ağ´A, see DefinitionÂ 3.1. Here, tğ‘¡t denotes the parameters of the Hornâ€“Kapranov uniformization of the Ağ´A-discriminant XË‡AsubscriptË‡ğ‘‹ğ´\check{X}_{A} and, hence, the cuspidal form depends also on a choice of Gale dual of Ağ´A. The name â€œcuspidal formâ€ reflects the fact that PAâ€‹(t)subscriptğ‘ƒğ´ğ‘¡P_{A}(t) describes the preimage of the cuspidal locus of XË‡AsubscriptË‡ğ‘‹ğ´\check{X}_{A} under the Hornâ€“Kapranov uniformaziation. In particular, as one observes immediately, the configuration Ağ´A is dual defective if and only if PAâ€‹(t)subscriptğ‘ƒğ´ğ‘¡P_{A}(t) is trivial.

The core part of this work is to describe the properties of the cuspidal form PAâ€‹(t)subscriptğ‘ƒğ´ğ‘¡P_{A}(t) as an invariant of the spectrum Ağ´A. Our main, technical, results are concerned with factorizations. For example, if Ağ´A is a diagonal configuration (DefinitionÂ 4.3), then the cuspidal form PAâ€‹(t)subscriptğ‘ƒğ´ğ‘¡P_{A}(t) factors as a product of the cuspidal forms of the diagonal configurations of Ağ´A.

We spend a fair amount of energy describing linear factors of PAâ€‹(t)subscriptğ‘ƒğ´ğ‘¡P_{A}(t). These are of two distinct types. The first type consists of linear factors corresponding to rows of the Gale dual. These factors correspond to points Î±âˆˆAğ›¼ğ´\alpha\in A such that Aâˆ–{Î±}ğ´ğ›¼A\setminus\{\alpha\} is dual defective. Such factors are studied in Â§4.1 and Â§5. The complementary type corresponds to discriminant varieties embedded into the cuspidal locus of XË‡AsubscriptË‡ğ‘‹ğ´\check{X}_{A}. This generalizes results of [11], where the cuspidal form first appeared in the special case of n=1ğ‘›1n=1 (when PAâ€‹(t)subscriptğ‘ƒğ´ğ‘¡P_{A}(t) is itself a linear form).

As an application, we extend Esterovâ€™s characterization from [4] and [5] of dual defective point configurations to the case of exponential sums: A point configuration Ağ´A is dual defective if and only if it does not contain any iterated circuit (TheoremÂ 6.4). Our proof uses in addition to the properties of the cuspidal form only the pidgeon hole principle.

Finally, in Â§8 we study the special case n=2ğ‘›2n=2 when PAâ€‹(t)subscriptğ‘ƒğ´ğ‘¡P_{A}(t) is a quadratic form. Defined only up to choice of coordinates of the parameter space â„‚msuperscriptâ„‚ğ‘š\mathbb{C}^{m} of the Hornâ€“Kapranov uniformization, it is natural to consider the rank of PAâ€‹(t)subscriptğ‘ƒğ´ğ‘¡P_{A}(t). We consider instead the signature of PAâ€‹(t)subscriptğ‘ƒğ´ğ‘¡P_{A}(t), which is a well-defined invariant of Ağ´A if we restrict to real Gale duals. It turns out (TheoremÂ 8.1) that the rank of PAâ€‹(t)subscriptğ‘ƒğ´ğ‘¡P_{A}(t) is at most 333, independent on the number of variables mğ‘šm. The degenerate case that the rank is at most 222 occurs if and only if the spectrum Ağ´A is contained in a conic section; the type of the conic section is described by the signature of PAâ€‹(t)subscriptğ‘ƒğ´ğ‘¡P_{A}(t). These results relate to the study of self-dual toric varieties as follows. Given a two-dimensional (integral) point configuration Ağ´A, the cusps of of the associated toric variety XAsubscriptğ‘‹ğ´X_{A} are (intuitively) contained in two lines. Hence, if XAsubscriptğ‘‹ğ´X_{A} is self dual, then PAâ€‹(t)subscriptğ‘ƒğ´ğ‘¡P_{A}(t) factors into linear forms, implying by TheoremÂ 8.1 that Ağ´A is contained in a conic section. For an explicit example, see the description of the Togliatti surface in [3, Â§4.1], whose spectrum consists of six points on an ellipse.

It is possible toconsider for example complex spectra instead of real. The Ağ´A-discriminant variety, in the sense of exponential sums, remains well-defined. The characterization of dual defective point configurations, as those who do not contain an iterated circuit, remains valid. However, for complex spectra, the relationship to combinatorics is lost, as we can for example not talk about Newton polygons. We have chosen to stay in the real world as this is the most interesting case for applications.

4.2. Diagonal and upper diagonal configurations

Definition 4.3.

We say that a point configuration Ağ´A is upper diagonal if it can, after acting by GL1+nâ¡(â„)subscriptGL1ğ‘›â„\operatorname{GL}_{1+n}(\mathbb{R}), be written in the form

6. Defect Duals

A point configuration Ağ´A and, in the algebraic case, the toric variety XAsubscriptğ‘‹ğ´X_{A}, is said to be dual defective if the dual variety XË‡AsubscriptË‡ğ‘‹ğ´\check{X}_{A} has codimension at least 222. The following theorem is an immediate consequence of the properties of the Jacobian matrix.

Theorem 6.1.

The point configuration Ağ´A is dual defective if and only if PAâ€‹(t)subscriptğ‘ƒğ´ğ‘¡P_{A}(t) is trivial.

Proof.

If Ağ´A is dual defective, then the rank of the Jacobian matrix Jâ€‹(w;t)ğ½ğ‘¤ğ‘¡J(w;t) is at most n+mâˆ’1ğ‘›ğ‘š1n+m-1 for generic (w;t)ğ‘¤ğ‘¡(w;t). It follows that its maximal minors, which are polynomial in (w;t)ğ‘¤ğ‘¡(w;t), vanishes for generic (w;t)ğ‘¤ğ‘¡(w;t), and hence they vanishes identically. Conversely, if XË‡AsubscriptË‡ğ‘‹ğ´\check{X}_{A} is a hypersurface, as the smooth locus of XË‡AsubscriptË‡ğ‘‹ğ´\check{X}_{A} is nonempty, we can find a point f=Î¦â€‹(w;t)ğ‘“Î¦ğ‘¤ğ‘¡f=\Phi(w;t) for which the Jacobian matrix Jâ€‹(w;t)ğ½ğ‘¤ğ‘¡J(w;t) has rank n+mğ‘›ğ‘šn+m. âˆ

Example 6.2.

Let Ağ´A be a pyramid. We saw in Example 3.2 that the polynomial PAâ€‹(t)subscriptğ‘ƒğ´ğ‘¡P_{A}(t) is trivial, implying (the well-known result) that XAsubscriptğ‘‹ğ´X_{A} is dual defective.

Proposition 6.3.

If Ağ´A has a subset Aâ€²superscriptğ´â€²A^{\prime}, of full dimension, such that Aâ€²superscriptğ´â€²A^{\prime} is not dual defective, then Ağ´A is not dual defective.

Proof.

This (well-known result) follows from Corollary 4.2. âˆ

Let us now recover Esterovâ€™s results on dual defective point configuration from [4, Lem.Â 3.17] and [5, Cor.Â 3.20], and extend it from the algebraic case to the case of exponential sums.

Theorem 6.4.

A specturm AâŠ‚â„1+nğ´superscriptâ„1ğ‘›A\subset\mathbb{R}^{1+n} is dual defective if and only if Ağ´A does not contain any iterated circuit.

7. Rationality of the Cuspidal Locus

Let Ağ´A be algebraic. Consider the case n=1ğ‘›1n=1, which was studied in detail in [11], and where the cuspidal form PAâ€‹(t)subscriptğ‘ƒğ´ğ‘¡P_{A}(t) appeared in this special case. As n=1ğ‘›1n=1 the cuspidal form is, for every mğ‘šm, a non-trivial linear form in tğ‘¡t vanishing along some hyperplane in â„™mâˆ’1superscriptâ„™ğ‘š1\mathbb{P}^{m-1}. In particular, the cuspidal locus of XË‡AsubscriptË‡ğ‘‹ğ´\check{X}_{A} is always unirational, and if it is a subvariety of XË‡AsubscriptË‡ğ‘‹ğ´\check{X}_{A} of codimension one, then it is rational. Actually, a stronger statement holds: there is a point configuration Eğ¸E such that the cuspidal locus of XË‡AsubscriptË‡ğ‘‹ğ´\check{X}_{A} is isomorphic to the discriminantal variety XË‡EsubscriptË‡ğ‘‹ğ¸\check{X}_{E}. Let us here explain the corresponding result for general nğ‘›n.

Theorem 7.1.

Let Ağ´A be algebraic. For each linear factor âŸ¨â„“,tâŸ©â„“ğ‘¡\langle\ell,t\rangle of PAâ€‹(t)subscriptğ‘ƒğ´ğ‘¡P_{A}(t), such that â„“â„“\ell is not proportional to any row of the Gale dual BğµB, there is an algebraic point configuration Eğ¸E whose discriminant XË‡EsubscriptË‡ğ‘‹ğ¸\check{X}_{E} is birational to a subvariety of the cuspidal locus of XË‡AsubscriptË‡ğ‘‹ğ´\check{X}_{A}.

Proof.

In the algebraic case it suffices to consider the reduced discriminant of Kapranov [8] mentioned in RemarkÂ 2.5. Its Hornâ€“Kapranov uniformazation Î¨Aâ€‹(t)subscriptÎ¨ğ´ğ‘¡\Psi_{A}(t) is given by tâ†¦Î¦â€‹(1;t)B=(Bâ€‹t)Bmaps-toğ‘¡Î¦superscript1ğ‘¡ğµsuperscriptğµğ‘¡ğµt\mapsto\Phi(1;t)^{B}=(Bt)^{B}.

Let âŸ¨â„“,tâŸ©â„“ğ‘¡\langle\ell,t\rangle be a linear factor of PAâ€‹(t)subscriptğ‘ƒğ´ğ‘¡P_{A}(t), where â„“â„“\ell is not proportional to any row of the Gale dual BğµB.   6. vi)

Proof of TheoremÂ 8.1.

It is well known that for n=2ğ‘›2n=2 the point configuration Ağ´A is dual defective if and only Ağ´A is a pyramid. This proves part (i) of the theorem.

If the codimension m=1ğ‘š1m=1, then Ağ´A consists of four points in the plane, through which two parabolas pass. It can be seen from (11) that the limiting case between real and non-real parabolas is the case of a pyramid. Thus, this case follows from ExampleÂ 3.3.

We now assume that m>1ğ‘š1m>1. Classical geometry says that there is a unique conic passing through five points in generic position (i.e., no four are colinear) in the plane. We allow the conic to be degenerate. Assuming that Ağ´A is not a pyramid, it has a subconfiguration A1subscriptğ´1A_{1} of five points in generic position. Let A1subscriptğ´1A_{1} constitute the first five columns of (7).

Let us first prove the relaxed statement, where we only consider the rank of the cuspidal form PAâ€‹(t)subscriptğ‘ƒğ´ğ‘¡P_{A}(t). It follows from LemmaÂ 8.4 that the rank is at most three.

If the rank is at most two, then by LemmaÂ 8.7 any choice of six points of Ağ´A is contained in a conic. However, the five points of A1subscriptğ´1A_{1} determine a unique conic Cğ¶C. By adjoining the remaining points one-by-one, we conclude that Ağ´A is contained in the conic Cğ¶C. Conversely, if Ağ´A is contained in a conic, then G3subscriptğº3G_{3} vanishes for all Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î´ğ›¿\delta by (9).

If the rank is at most one, then by LemmaÂ 8.5 any choice of five points is contained in a parabola. In particular, the five points of A1subscriptğ´1A_{1} are contained in a parabola Cğ¶C. Let Î±ğ›¼\alpha be an additional point. Then, by LemmaÂ 8.7, A1âˆª{Î±}subscriptğ´1ğ›¼A_{1}\cup\{\alpha\} is contained in a conic. But Cğ¶C is the unique conic containing A1subscriptğ´1A_{1}, so Î±âˆˆCğ›¼ğ¶\alpha\in C. It follows that Ağ´A is contained in Cğ¶C. Conversely, if Ağ´A is contained in a parabola, then G2subscriptğº2G_{2} vanishes for all Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î´ğ›¿\delta by LemmaÂ 8.5 and RemarkÂ 8.6.

Let us now turn to the refined statement of TheoremÂ 8.1 regarding signatures. For each class in the above list, it suffices to consider the minimal mğ‘šm such that there is a point configuration in this class. Indeed, there is a â€œminimalâ€ subconfiguration witnessing the class containing Ağ´A, and by TheoremÂ 4.1 we can delete the remaining points without altering the rank. In particular, parts (ii) and (iii) follows from the above discussion on codimension m=1ğ‘š1m=1.

Any two minimal configurations of one class can be continuously deformed to each other without leaving the class in question. Therefor, it suffices to consider one representative of each class. Since a generic configuration can be continuously deformed to a configuration contained either in an ellipse or in a parabola, part (vi) follows from parts (iv) and (v) and the fact that the rank is 333 in the generic case. Hence, we finish the proof with Examples 8.8 and 8.9. âˆ
